content:
Morgan Rogers said:

I said "simplicial complex", intending "geometric realisation of the category", since Quillen's theorem also talks about the classifying space. I don't know homotopy theory well enough to know how a fibrant replacement of a simplicial set is constructed.

Anyway, there's a “quick and kind of useless” way which is to take the singular complex of the geometric realisation, and a “more complicated but very useful” combinatorial way involving an iteration of Kan's Ex\mathrm{Ex}Ex functor, the adjoint of barycentric subdivision.
I think that what I said should be provable using the latter construction, but this is the point where I would rather just look up the proof :D

Right, Ex\mathrm{Ex}Ex is useful here. It suffices to show that Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC) is contractible. An nnn-sphere in Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC) is the same as a map sd(∂Δ[n])→NC\mathrm{sd}(\partial \Delta[n]) \to NCsd(∂Δ[n])→NC, and a cocone over this diagram is the same as a map sd(Δ[n])→NC\mathrm{sd}(\Delta[n]) \to NCsd(Δ[n])→NC, i.e. a filler for the original sphere in Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC).

I think we should keep spaces in the mix for the purposes of computing examples, because I reckon that I should get a homotopy-equivalent space from any suitable presentation of my monoid (with a 1-simplex for each generator and suitable cells to provide homotopies between related composites), which for finitely generated monoids would be a massive advantage.

Paolo Capriotti said:

Right, Ex\mathrm{Ex}Ex is useful here. It suffices to show that Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC) is contractible. An nnn-sphere in Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC) is the same as a map sd(∂Δ[n])→NC\mathrm{sd}(\partial \Delta[n]) \to NCsd(∂Δ[n])→NC, and a cocone over this diagram is the same as a map sd(Δ[n])→NC\mathrm{sd}(\Delta[n]) \to NCsd(Δ[n])→NC, i.e. a filler for the original sphere in Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC).

I will need all of the notation explaining, if you don't mind :sweat_smile:
ie how are you constructing Ex and/or how can I think about it?

Paolo Capriotti said:

Right, Ex\mathrm{Ex}Ex is useful here. It suffices to show that Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC) is contractible. An nnn-sphere in Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC) is the same as a map sd(∂Δ[n])→NC\mathrm{sd}(\partial \Delta[n]) \to NCsd(∂Δ[n])→NC, and a cocone over this diagram is the same as a map sd(Δ[n])→NC\mathrm{sd}(\Delta[n]) \to NCsd(Δ[n])→NC, i.e. a filler for the original sphere in Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC).

Thanks! Is there a reason why doing a single round of Ex\mathrm{Ex}Ex is sufficient?

Morgan Rogers said:

ie how are you constructing Ex and/or how can I think about it?

By adjointness: nnn-simplices in Ex(X)\mathrm{Ex}(X)Ex(X) are the same as maps sd(Δ[n])→X\mathrm{sd}(\Delta[n]) \to Xsd(Δ[n])→X, i.e. barycentrically subdivided simplices in XXX...
There is a way of including XXX into Ex(X)\mathrm{Ex}(X)Ex(X) via a natural way of mapping the subdivision of a simplex onto the simplex (all the maximal simplices but one get tossed onto a vertex)

Where sd means subdivision and Δ[n]\Delta[n]Δ[n] is your notation for the n-simplex, okay.
You say "natural", but I can see at least nnn ways of doing that :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
I think there's exactly two of them that are functorial :)

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

Thanks! Is there a reason why doing a single round of Ex\mathrm{Ex}Ex is sufficient?

I was thinking something along these lines: you prove that if XXX is a filtered simplicial set (i.e. satisfies a right orthogonality property analogous to the definition of filtered for categories), then Ex(X)\mathrm{Ex}(X)Ex(X) is contractible, and this is basically the argument above. Now by induction all the Exn(NC)\mathrm{Ex}^n(NC)Exn(NC) are contractible, so the colimit should also be contractible.
What is the "right orthogonality property" you're referring to?
These facts about Ex can be found in Kerodon 3.3.5 and its containing section
something like right lifting property with respect to maps N(J)→N(J)∗Δ[0]N(J) \to N(J) \ast \Delta[0]N(J)→N(J)∗Δ[0], where JJJ is a finite category
where ∗\ast∗ is join
... join? Do you mean N(J)∗Δ[0]N(J) * \Delta[0]N(J)∗Δ[0] is the cone under/over N(J)N(J)N(J) in the geometric sense?
yes

I've never seen that given as "the" definition of filtered before, but then much of the notation/terminology used in this topic has been a little alien to me. I can see how this is a convenient form for this definition in this context.

But since X→Ex(X)X \to \mathrm{Ex}(X)X→Ex(X) is a weak equivalence (as that Kerodon page shows), you actually don't need the whole inductive argument above: if Ex(X)\mathrm{Ex}(X)Ex(X) is contractible, then (the fibrant replacement of) XXX is contractible.
Maybe I'm wrong, but I think a gap with the argument above is that you can't check contractibility by only “filling boundaries of standard n-simplices” unless you are in a Kan complex
Which is why you need to look at the ∂Δ[n]→Ex∞(NC)\partial \Delta[n] \to \mathrm{Ex}^\infty(NC)∂Δ[n]→Ex∞(NC)
But these are going to land into Exk(NC)\mathrm{Ex}^k(NC)Exk(NC) for a finite kkk, so then I think you can just apply your argument with sdk(∂Δ[n])\mathrm{sd}^k(\partial \Delta[n])sdk(∂Δ[n])
Filling boundaries automatically gives that it is Kan complex, because the map X→1X \to 1X→1 is a trivial fibration (hence a fibration).
Ah of course! That's the step I was missing. :)
Is it always the case that Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC) is a Kan complex, or is there something special about CCC being contractible?
I don't think it is always the case. It is probably related to some Ore condition or similar. But I'm not sure.
For example, if C=∙←∙→∙C= \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bulletC=∙←∙→∙, then it seems you cannot fill 2-horns in Ex(NC)\mathrm{Ex}(NC)Ex(NC). But double check :)
Should I ask what a 2-horn is..?
A 2-dimensional horn
i.e. two lines glued by a vertex
That sounds 1-dimensional! But okay, I'm relieved that it's simpler than I expected.

Yes, it's really 1-dimensional, but the index is 2, because you always think of the nnn-horns Λi[n]\Lambda^i[n]Λi[n] it as the domains of the horn inclusions Λi[n]→Δ[n]\Lambda^i[n] \to \Delta[n]Λi[n]→Δ[n], and Δ[n]\Delta[n]Δ[n] is nnn-dimensional, of course. Here iii is the face that you removed from the boundary. Being a Kan complex means that every map Λi[n]→X\Lambda^i[n] \to XΛi[n]→X can be extended to Δ[n]\Delta[n]Δ[n].
hmm, seems inconsistent with the fact that, say, the n-sphere is the boundary of the n+1-ball...
But it's consistent notationally with the simplicial nnn-sphere, namely ∂Δ[n+1]\partial \Delta[n+1]∂Δ[n+1].
